channel.title: NPR All Things Considered
channel.description: All Things Considered hosts Ailsa Chang, Mary Louise Kelly, Ari Shapiro, Juana Summers and Scott Detrow present the program's trademark mix of news, interviews, commentaries, reviews, and offbeat features 7 days a week.

item.title: More people in the U.S. are catching on to a European idea: backyard solar panels
item.description: What if you could set up some panels in your backyard or hang them off your balcony and start making a dent in your power bill? Organizations are trying to bring "balcony solar" to the U.S.

item.title: Sheila Jordan, one of the great underappreciated voices in jazz, dies at age 96
item.description: She recorded a magical debut album on Blue Note and was later named a Jazz Master by the National Endowment of the Arts.

item.title: How the Secret Service arranges a short notice trip like Trump's meeting in Alaska
item.description: The president will meet with Putin on Friday in Alaska. A former secret service agent shares how the service plans last minute trips like this, especially one with major geopolitical implications.

item.title: This music project uses bluegrass to bring people on the autism spectrum together
item.description: A new effort led by Hollywood composer John Frizzell seeks to connect people with autism to each other through bluegrass.

item.title: Ford and the promise of cheaper EVs
item.description: Ford announced they're putting billions into a Kentucky automotive plant to retool it to make EVs, starting with a midsize pickup that they say will be in the $30k price range.

item.title: Remembering the Bulwer-Lytton Fiction Contest — a contest for bad writing
item.description: For four decades, an English professor at San Jose State University has run a fiction contest for a single opening sentence to "the worst of all possible novels." He has decided to retire the contest.

item.title: Chair of D.C. Council responds to Trump's emergency declaration
item.description: NPR's Ari Shapiro speaks with chair of the Council of the District of Columbia, Phil Mendelson, about President Trump's emergency declaration and National Guard deployment in Washington, D.C.

item.title: Gaza's 'White Walkers' — the deadly task of simply getting flour
item.description: For multiple days, more people are killed trying to get food in Gaza than in Israeli air strikes, medics say.

item.title: Murder in a small town means 'We Are All Guilty Here,' writes novelist Karin Slaughter
item.description: Karin Slaughter talks about her 25th book -- "We are All Guilty Here" - with NPR's Mary Louise Kelly. It's a small town murder mystery - that twists and turns until the end.

item.title: The solar system's third interstellar visitor, 3I/ATLAS, is zooming by at 130,000 mph
item.description: NPR's Ari Shapiro talks with astronomer David Jewitt about what we can learn from the third interstellar object to have entered our solar system, a comet-like object known as 3I/ATLAS.
